StoryElement.StoryElement: [A phone rings. Robby opens his eyes and gropes in a dark room for the phone. He finds the receiver and puts it to his ear.]
ROBBY: I didn’t order a wake up call.
MARIKO: I’m just making sure you’re not late for your first day of work.
ROBBY: Thanks. When’s breakfast?
MARIKO: Grab a quick bite and then meet me in the lobby in a half an hour! We’re busy busy busy ...
ROBBY: Yes ma'am.
[Robby hangs up the phone.]

ROBBY: I should just leave right now. This is crazy! I’m going to take a quick shower, go down to the lobby, talk to Mariko and get this straitened out. Maybe my parents can wire me the money. I wonder what time it is in America? It’s probably . . .
[Robby opens the door to the bathroom and is surprised to see Junko putting on her makeup.]
JUNKO: Aaah!
ROBBY: Sorry! What are you doing here?
JUNKO: This is my room too! And thanks to your little deal with Mariko, I’m already late for work!

StoryResponse.StoryResponse: JUNKO: Get out of here! Let me change.
JUNKO: What?!! Get out of here!

StoryElement.StoryElement: [Robby sits in front of a stack of envelopes.]
ROBBY: This isn’t exactly what I had in mind.
ROBBY: All of these?
MARIKO: Would you rather be scrubbing the locker room floors?
ROBBY: Frankly, yes.
MARIKO: Maybe we’ll find time for that later. For now, start inserting these papers into these envelopes.
ROBBY: Where’s Junko?
MARIKO: She’s doing house-cleaning duties.
ROBBY: So you gave me the fun job?
MARIKO: I thought it would be weird if a foreigner in a staff uniform suddenly showed up at a guest’s room and started tidying up the place.
ROBBY: Doesn’t sound weird to me.
MARIKO: Better get to work. There are three more boxes of those papers we need to send out. Oh, and just one more thing. Don’t go into that room there, that’s the employee room.
ROBBY: You don’t have to worry about me. I have enough in here to keep me interested.
MARIKO: I think you have an expression for this: 'It’s time to pay the man who plays the pipe.'
ROBBY: You mean, 'the piper'. The man who plays the pipe is called the piper.
MARIKO: Well, it’s better than paying with your nose.
ROBBY: It’s through your . . . never mind.
[Mariko leaves.]
ROBBY: This is great. Maybe Mariko is right. It’s time to pay the piper. Oh well, it’s only one day. Here’s one in the envelope. One down, five gajillion to go.
ROBBY: At least it’s not so bad. I get to work in a place full of beautiful women . . . and one angry boss.
[THE END]
